results.title: You will see me
results.creator_credit: Conor Bateman, Field Carr and Sari Braithwaite
results.brief_description: You will see me explores the way artists and amateurs alike have turned the camera on themselves since they became more accessible in the mid-20th century, and how this tradition is continued, amplified and tranformed through reality TV, the internet and social media.

constellations_primary.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_primary.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

results.description: The camera doesn’t just capture us, it frames who we are and how we’re seen. Since the camera became more accessible in the mid-20th century, artists and amateurs alike have turned the lens on themselves to create a stage both private and public. This tradition is continued, amplified and transformed through reality TV, the internet and social media, the latest forms to use straight-to-camera techniques to share our common humanity, project authenticity and illuminate how a sense of self can be constructed through the moving image.

results.title: Grand Théâtre Fantasmagorique shadow play set
results.brief_description: Shadow play sets used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Popular in China for over 2000 years, they were later merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.

constellations_primary.name: Spooky shadows
constellations_primary.description: Hellish and hilarious vampires connect pioneering German cinema to contemporary New Zealand comedy with a quick detour into small town strangeness.

results.description:
Shadow puppetry has been popular in China for more than 2,000 years. Invented to entertain Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty, shadow plays were transported to Europe by travellers in the mid-18th century. There they were known as ombres chinoises (Chinese shadows) and were adapted to tell European stories. Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.

results.title: Hacknet
results.creator_credit: Fellow Traveller and Team Fractal Alligator
results.brief_description: Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

constellations_primary.name: Hack the planet
constellations_primary.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

results.description:
If you’ve ever wanted to know what hacking is really like, Hacknet is the game for you. Simulating a true-to-life terminal environment, the game tasks the player with using computer commands similar to what a real hacker would use. These skills are put to use solving the murder of a character named Bit, who contacts the player through a computer program initiated after their death.

Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

results.title: Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You
results.brief_description: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949).

constellations_primary.name: Orwell & Snowden
constellations_primary.description: Explores Orwell as a representation of the NSA, and the infamous Snowden leak.

results.description: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949). Transforming the dystopian thriller into a click-and-play game set in our contemporary online world, players are cast as government operatives who trawl social media profiles to uncover terrorists and political dissidents. Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You presents players with moral dilemmas, forcing them to think about their own ethics and beliefs when responding to the game’s reflection of our current society. It also asks them to analyse the effect of surveillance culture on society and the proliferation of false information and fake news.

results.title: Flower
results.brief_description: When Jenova Chen and Nicholas Clark designed Flower, they approached it as more of an interactive artwork than a traditional videogame.

constellations_primary.name: Flower on the wind
constellations_primary.description: Explore the use of flowers in the moving image as an aesthetic and metaphor.

results.description:
When Jenova Chen and Nicholas Clark designed Flower, they approached it as more of an interactive artwork than a traditional videogame.

Flower lets you control the wind as it blows a single flower petal around the stages. The petal interacts with various elements in the world, triggering wind turbines or rejuvenating the landscape.

Rather than focus on traditional design principles of ‘fun’ or challenging gameplay, Chen and Clark instead worked to create a meditative experience they hoped would provoke positive emotions in the player.

results.title: Headliner: NoviNews
results.brief_description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society.

constellations_primary.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_primary.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

results.description:
Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society. Players take the role of a ‘headliner’, which is like a chief editor at a news outlet. The player must decide what stories and angles to publish, and their choices have wide-reaching effects in the game world. Reject stories about creating national healthcare services? People get sick in the street. Approve stories on the benefits of synthetic recreational drugs? Addiction runs rampant.

These stories aren’t presented as obviously ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ choices: the game lets the player’s own ethics and morals guide their decisions – which can create a peaceful society or burn it to the ground.

results.title: Observation
results.brief_description: The space station Observation is twirling through the cosmos, the power cut and the crew missing. Players must help solve the mystery by taking control of SAM (Systems Administration Maintenance), the station’s AI software that’s based on HAL from Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968).

constellations_primary.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_primary.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

results.description:
The space station Observation is twirling through the cosmos, the power cut and the crew missing. The station’s lone occupant is Dr Emma Fisher, who players must help solve the mystery by taking control of SAM (Systems Administration Maintenance), the station’s AI software that’s based on HAL from Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968). This sci-fi thriller draws inspiration from many similar interstellar-set horror stories and puts players in command of a potentially malevolent AI.

The developers were intrigued by the question of whether AI could even be evil or if its code had somehow failed it. Observation players get to explore that idea, and their actions as SAM affect the game world and story.

results.title: Canopy
results.credit_line:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe
results.brief_description: John Harvey’s multi-screen installation, Canopy, celebrates and shares First Peoples self-representation while resisting and disrupting popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood too often defined by the white gaze of non-Indigenous filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Canopy
constellations_primary.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

results.description:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey
